How It Works

1

Submit Your Problem

Pay $20, describe your problem, and you're in the queue. You'll see your position on this page.

2

Wait for Your Turn

We pick 2 problems per day - one from the top, one at random. Each gets up to 1 hour of focused attention.

3

Get Your Results

If a video is published, it will appear on FogSift YouTube. You also receive a direct reply via your requested contact method.

4

Want It Faster?

Use the bump option to move up in the queue. One bump per day keeps it fair.

5

Need Something Custom?

The queue is for quick hits. For deeper work, check out our custom work requests.

About Public Work Pages

By default, your work session is public. Your problem and our solution get documented here for others to learn from. This transparency is what makes FogSift work.

Want privacy? Request anonymization or "no public page" when you submit. Must be specified at submission time.

=======

The Queue

Submit your problem. I pick two per day. One highest-rated, one random. Work happens live on camera.

Join the Queue ($20)

HOW IT WORKS

1

Submit

Pay $20 and describe your problem. Be specific about what's stuck.

2

Wait

Your problem enters the queue. I pick 2 per day: one top-rated, one random.

3

Watch

I work your problem live on camera for up to an hour. You get the video + a written summary.

QUEUE STATUS

-- In Queue
-- Completed
-- Avg Wait (days)

Queue data updates when sessions are completed.

RECENT SESSIONS

Watch previous sessions on YouTube to see how this works.

Watch on YouTube

What You Get

  • Video of the work session - Watch my actual thought process as I tackle your problem
  • Written summary - Key findings, recommendations, and next steps
  • Public by default - Others can learn from your problem (anonymization available)

What Makes a Good Submission?

  • Specific - "Our checkout flow has a 67% drop-off" beats "sales are bad"
  • Bounded - Something I can meaningfully address in an hour
  • Actionable - You're ready to act on what we find

Privacy Options

By default, sessions are public so others can learn. If your problem involves sensitive details, you can request anonymization. I'll obscure identifying information while keeping the diagnostic process visible.
